unnormalised: Someone asked me about train travel in India, and honestly, it’s an experience. I remember my first solo trip from Delhi to Guwahati on the Rajdhani Express. I was 18, nervous as hell, and my parents had given me a whole lecture about safety. The ticket was WL (Waiting List), but thankfully it got confirmed 4 hrs before departure.
normalised: Someone asked me about train travel in India, and honestly, it’s an experience. I remember my first solo trip from Delhi to Guwahati on the Rajdhani Express. I was eighteen, nervous as hell, and my parents had given me a whole lecture about safety. The ticket was W-L (Waiting List), but thankfully it got confirmed four hours before departure.

unnormalised: The train was scheduled to depart at 16:10 hrs. I reached the station at 3:30 PM, lugging a massive suitcase filled with clothes I probably wouldn't even wear. The platform was chaotic. People were everywhere, chai vendors were shouting, and the air smelled of samosas and diesel. I finally found my coach, B3, and somehow squeezed myself and my suitcase inside.
normalised: The train was scheduled to depart at sixteen ten hours. I reached the station at three thirty P-M, lugging a massive suitcase filled with clothes I probably wouldn't even wear. The platform was chaotic. People were everywhere, chai vendors were shouting, and the air smelled of samosas and diesel. I finally found my coach, B three, and somehow squeezed myself and my suitcase inside.

unnormalised: Inside, it was a whole other world. My seat was 37, side lower berth. My co-passengers were a mix of families going home, students heading to college, and a couple of business travellers. One uncle, Mr. Sharma, was particularly helpful, showing me how to secure my luggage and telling me stories about his travels all over India. We crossed so many places like Patna, Mughal Sarai. The journey took almost 27 hrs.

One uncle, Mister Sharma, was particularly helpful, showing me how to secure my luggage and telling me stories about his travels all over India. We crossed so many places like Patna, Mughal Sarai. The journey took almost twenty seven hours.

unnormalised: The food was okay, not great, but definitely filling. They served lunch, dinner, and breakfast. I remember the bill being Rs. 150 for a veg thali. Also the vendors selling snacks, books and other items kept coming at regular intervals. The scenery outside was incredible - lush green fields, tiny villages, and rivers sparkling in the sunlight. I even managed to catch a glimpse of the sunset over the Ganges.
normalised: The food was okay, not great, but definitely filling. They served lunch, dinner, and breakfast. I remember the bill being rupee one hundred and fifty for a veg thali. Also the vendors selling snacks, books and other items kept coming at regular intervals. The scenery outside was incredible - lush green fields, tiny villages, and rivers sparkling in the sunlight. I even managed to catch a glimpse of the sunset over the Ganges.

unnormalised: Overall, despite the initial anxiety and the slightly chaotic atmosphere, my train journey was unforgettable. It's a microcosm of India itself - diverse, vibrant, and full of surprises. Would I do it again? Absolutely. Just remember to book your tickets well in advance and carry a good book to keep you entertained! And maybe some hand sanitizer.
